Sentencas: In the present study, a detailed thermodynamic analysis is carried out to provide useful information for the operation of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC) with direct internal reforming (DIR) fueled by ethanol.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: Equilibrium calculations are performed to find the ranges of inlet steam/ethanol (H2O/EtOH) ratio where carbon formation is thermodynamically unfavorable in the temperature range of 500-1500 K. Two types of fuel cell electrolytes, i.e., oxygen-conducting, and hydrogen-conducting electrolytes, are considered.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: The key parameters determining the boundary of carbon formation are temperature, type of solid electrolyte and extent of the electrochemical reaction of hydrogen.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: The minimum H2O/EtOH ratio for which the carbon fort-nation is thermodynamically unfavored decreases with increasing temperature.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: The hydrogen-conducting electrolyte is found to be impractical for use, due to the tendency for carbon formation.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: With a higher extent of the electrochemical reaction of hydrogen, a higher value of the H2O/EtOH ratio is required for the hydrogen-conducting electrolyte, whereas a smaller value is required for the oxygen-conducting electrolyte.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol

Sentencas: This difference is due mainly to the water formed by the electrochemical reaction at the electrodes.
Titulo: Thermodynamic analysis for a solid oxide fuel cell with direct internal reforming fueled by ethanol
